result.markdown:
--- title: "snake_case vs Everything_Else" author: "al" date: "2024-05-07" format: html: code-fold: true categories: [news] --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo=TRUE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, dpi=60, out.width = "100%") options(scipen=999) options(knitr.kable.NA = '--') #'--' options(knitr.kable.NAN = '--') ``` ::: Been preferring `snakecase` naming convention for all files and columns and variables for a long time for the following reasons: 1. It's much easier to type. Reaching for the shift button is a pain. 2. Arguably easier to read. I find it easier to read `snake_case` than `CamelCase`. 3. Can make it easy to `name` things in a fashion that allows you to dissect what something is by the way it is named and allows automatic sorting to group similar things together. This is a good read - https://speakerdeck.com/jennybc/how-to-name-files-the-sequel . This pays homage to one of my favorite programmers right now who is [Michael Sumner](https://github.com/mdsumner). His tag line on `github` is "no names have an anonymous function". ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::include_graphics("thumbnail.jpg") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](thumbnail.jpg){#fig-snake_vs_camel width=100%} ::: ::: Worth noting that `sometimes-rules-need-to-be-broken` sometimes such as when you are naming chunks in `Rmarkdown`. It breaks our `cross-references`.
As we see here though - it doesn't matter in `Quarto` (ex. see @fig-snake_vs_camel) vs @fig-all). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} knitr::include_graphics("all.jpeg") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](all.jpeg){#fig-all width=100%} ::: :::
